title: Bill Belichick breaks down what went right for the Patriots and wrong for the Chargers
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots The Chargers fell behind early and couldn't muster enough offense to match the Patriots.

Bill Belichick AP Photo/Chris Seward Bill Belichick had a hunch that things would be difficult for the Chargers if they had to play from behind against the Patriots during last Sunday’s NFL wild-card matchup.

He mentioned the Chargers’ offensive line woes after losing tackles Rashawn Slater and Joe Alt to season-ending injuries, along with Justin Herbert’s injured hands as reasons why a Los Angeles comeback would have been difficult.

title: Beloved venue The Burren will be re-homed as part of a major Somerville redevelopment
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Business The Copper Mill project, which includes a 26-story residential tower, reached agreements with both The Burren and Dragon Pizza.
Outside The Burren in Somerville, Massachusetts.

title: From rent control to recreational pot, these 11 questions could be coming to Mass. ballots this fall
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Politics Massachusetts voters could be faced with a record-setting number of ballot questions in 2026.
Massachusetts voters could see 11 ballot questions in 2026.

title: Historic Dugout Cafe dive bar to sell its liquor license to chain restaurant
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Food News The listed price for the all-alcohol liquor license is $550,000, according to an attorney representing Earls Kitchen + Bar.
The Mendoza Line, seen here, was a weekly comedy show that took place at the historic Dugout Cafe.

Handout The Dugout Cafe, a nearly-century-old dive bar open in Boston since Prohibition’s end, was approved to give its liquor license to a Canadian chain of restaurants looking to open a third location in Greater Boston.

title: Hartford investigating after apparent federal employees deploy pepper spray, drive through protesters, mayor says
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Local News “We’re in uncharted territory, but we're going to treat it like any other crime that happened in the City of Hartford,” Mayor Arunan Arulampalam said.
Yuki Iwamura / AP, File By Molly Farrar January 13, 2026 | 10:32 AM 3 minutes to read ShareSend this article to your social connections.

Apparent federal employees who drove through a group of protesters attempting to block their exit, striking one, and who deployed pepper spray in the incident last week in Hartford could face criminal charges, the city’s mayor said.
